Message.Title: Techstrategy: let's be honest: the sepculative behavior you comment on all is possible b/c of the Fed's easy money
Message.Msg: They are the ones supplying it though daily QE POMO operations, buidling to the sky the Fed balance sheet higher and higher, and, subsequently, you have pockets here of anstronomical, histocially, high valuations being chased repeatedly, with little regard for risk. It would not be possible wihout the easy money. And the Fed, whether right or wrong, seems not a least concerned with bubbles that it makes. In fact, many of the members have commented on the fact that they can't identify bubbles until after the fact, and then deal with them, which is complete BS in my opinion. They supply the "crack" that allow it all. Somewhere along the way the over the last few decades, the Fed stopped ever taking the punchbowl away from speculative excess builtup. In fact here, they appear to pull out even more ways , via QE balance sheet expansion( which is paper currency devaluation) in order to keep the punchbowl spiked. In fact, it shows that the Fed was created by JP Morgan types in 1913, in order to bail out /buffer the rich holding assets at the expense of anything else. Your argument of reaching a higher moral ground is one of failure up to now. There was absolutley no morality in how Geithner /Bernanke bailed out bad bets and continue to use the QE function to goose,in many cases, risk taking assets.

Topic.Title: Techstrategy: let's be honest: the sepculative behavior you comment on all is possible b/c of the Fed's easy money

Message.Msg: The Fed is doing the bidding of its owners, not the public or taxpayer's interest, on that I agree. It is trying to ensure the correction comes from inflating debts away rather than writing them off (which is the correct path (IMHO). But, the structure of the market is to blame for this bubble. HFT quant/algo trading and longs who've tranformed models to collect "rent" from options have created a completely reflexive, internally imbalanced market.

Topic.Title: Techstrategy: let's be honest: the sepculative behavior you comment on all is possible b/c of the Fed's easy money

Message.Msg: But all the bubbles of the last 13 years involve the Fed easy money gone too far. You seem to always be a Fed apologist on this point. This isn't a new phenomena to this bull. It's happened in past instances as well. The market wouldn't be able to have such leverage speculation if the Fed, via Keynesian Crackonomics over the top, didn't act like a gambling parlor owner instead of a responsible Central Banks Institution. Even these weekly options instruments are born out of the fact that the Fed supplys the crack that allows them to be "born." I'll agree with you on the Fed merely being a pawn to it's masters, the banks and Wallstreet. Whatever the case, we're wll into, what I'm seeing, as the second biggerst asst bubble in the Nasdaq that I've ever seen. And it looks like it's about to go seriously parabolic. It certainly might here.

Message.Msg: Yep, I agree. Bernanke's reputation will be certainly far worse than now, which is being hailed as a bit of hero, if not super-hero. And yep, reminescent of nasdaq bubble of 2000. FED might "taper" in the future but I don't think FED can stop QE completely until certain economic stats improves. For example, labor participation rate, new homeowner numbers, money velocities. They all keep going DOWN since the beginning of great recession in 2008 !. It is very strange that we have elevated GDP, stock and real estate market while these stats keep going down !

Message.Title: Equities are NOT in a Bubble.
Message.Msg: Equities are in NO way in a bubble territory... call me when the S&P hits 25x p/e - Sure some stocks are expensive and some are cheap.. but the overall market is NOT expensive. Flow of Funds will take US much higher. The FED in EVERY recession has lowered Rates to Stimulate the Economy - no difference this go around. Except we were in a Depression, so rates have stayed lower, longer. AMZN is the poster child for Deflationary Pressures -- started with Books, then all Consumer Goods, Now Business Service (AWS) and now Consumer Services Trend carefully.

Topic.Title: Equities are NOT in a Bubble.

Message.Msg: They are in a bubble. Cyclically adjusted P/E ratios are bubbly. P/E ratios are also outrageously high in terms of growth rates. P/E/G ratios are higher than 2007... The ONLY thing supporting equity valuations is that bonds yields are so low. But bonds are a senior claim on assets/cash flows...

Topic.Title: Equities are NOT in a Bubble.

Message.Msg: And one more thing: this is a confined bubble to WS: most of the public is out and not goona come in a buy the leverge built up here of chasing AMZN type stuff after 5 years of it. It's the 1 % bubble. I suggest you look back at the early 1970's the last time you had a 1 % type bubble. Bernanke is a bubble nutjob and so are you if you think this isn't a bubble. it may grow more reckless and biggger, but tell me one leader tech stock that's been chased up parabolically the last year that doesn't sport a 200 PE or more: and i"m talking about the last Greenspan bubbble blow in CSCO, SUNW, INTC,and MSFT type stuff: I'm talking about the new ones here that replaced e'm. If Bernanke is gonna assist in making BEZOS the richest on earth, he could atleast try to get them to have some retained earnings and not a sport a PE of "N/a" while trading over 300. It makes the USA look like a paper tiger creating ceating welath effect paper nonsense engineering that does even come close to real price stability. In fact this more likely to turn into trouble the more speculatation he fuels. You are neophyte. I 've to see many a bubble and this is one. Just a matter of how big the nutjobs make it before, thank god, something comes along to shove it up their keister.
